BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Natural moist avalanches are possible from the morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong adjacent to ridgelines especially in the regions that are exposed to the foehn wind. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line large wind slabs formed.
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released naturally in particular on east to south to west facing aspects. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow and on wind-loaded slopes more large avalanches are possible, in particular in case of releases originating from starting zones that still retain some snow. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant and generally above the tree line. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 70 to 90 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. In all altitude zones a very large amount of snow is lying.
As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last three days. In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The new snow of the last few days remains for the foreseeable future prone to triggering and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. In the last few days large and very large avalanches were observed. The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the new snow slab avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A lot of snow has fallen over a wide area. Not yet all starting zones have released the snow entirely.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong over a wide area. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line further wind slabs formed. In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more medium-sized and large avalanches are possible. The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying in all altitude zones. Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. The new snow of the weekend has settled to a large extent in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In the last few days medium-sized to large avalanches were observed. The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Natural moist avalanches are possible from the morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate to strong at times especially in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line further wind slabs formed. In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more medium-sized and large avalanches are possible. The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. Weak layers exist in the old snowpack. In addition wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In the last few days medium-sized to large avalanches were observed. The high temperatures in the late morning will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution. The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found also on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. Released avalanches and reports filed by observers confirm the unfavourable bonding of the snowpack. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Such avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are difficult to recognise.

The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places in particular on shady slopes.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated critically. More gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of these avalanche prone locations will increase. They can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanches can in many cases reach medium size.
From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a significant increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches to level 3 (considerable). Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches in some places, including large ones. Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered. This applies in all aspects.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a significant increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A clear night will be followed in the early morning by sometimes favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase later.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of these avalanche prone locations will increase. They can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanches can in many cases reach medium size.
From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a significant increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches to level 3 (considerable). Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches in some places, including large ones. Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered. This applies in all aspects.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: From the late morning as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a significant increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found also on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes above approximately 2600 m. Released avalanches and reports filed by observers confirm the unfavourable bonding of the snowpack. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Such avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are difficult to recognise.

The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places in particular on shady slopes.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding avalanches can also occur.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as in places that are protected from the wind. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be quite large. In addition medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some snow will fall on Wednesday in some regions. On Wednesday the wind will be moderate to strong at times. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on soft layers above approximately 2200 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in particular at intermediate altitudes. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate altitudes. As a consequence of the occasionally strong wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size during the last few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual decrease in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. Gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible on Thursday, even large ones in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places in particular on shady slopes.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow of the weekend represents the main danger. This snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. The off-piste conditions are to some extent critical. Temporary safety measures may be necessary.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, will fall until the early morning above approximately 1800 m. The covering of new snow is soft. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Avalanches can in very isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable.

From origins in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place more gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places in particular on shady slopes.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. Snow slides and natural avalanches are still possible. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain. Gliding avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 1800 m. Avalanches can still be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack. In addition the sometimes new snow-covered wind slabs must be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases moist. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual, then as a consequence of solar radiation more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Hardly any more gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind will be moderate to strong over a wide area. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. In all aspects small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches are possible. Avalanches can as before be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be sunny at times.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the moisture increases individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible. Above approximately 1900 m and in gullies and bowls the danger of moist and wet avalanches is a little higher. This applies in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains quite favourable. Below approximately 1600 m hardly any snow is lying. The fresh and older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. Slow warming: These weather conditions will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a gradual weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses.
